data.name: CIS 122 #8 Input Validation
data.description:
This kata builds on the previous kata:

* [CIS 122 #1 Simple Printing](http://www.codewars.com/kata/55cd156ead636caae3000099)
* [CIS 122 #2 Simple Input](http://www.codewars.com/kata/55ceadf20f7ff25be1000026)
* [CIS 122 #3 Simple Operations](http://www.codewars.com/kata/55e2279fe6beae2d3700007b)
* [CIS 122 #4 Modules and Parameters](http://www.codewars.com/kata/55e8ec4f6e59675b2f0000f7)
* [CIS 122 #5 Functions and Return Values](http://www.codewars.com/kata/55ea0bbbf6d229c1c90000ff)
* [CIS 122 #6 Selection](http://www.codewars.com/kata/55eb511767a9e66a5900005b)
* [CIS 122 #7 Repetition](http://www.codewars.com/kata/55eba75a742310010400005f)

In this challenge, we'll be learning about how to validate user input. The pseudocode standard used in this challenge is based on the book [Starting Out with Programming Logic and Design, 3rd Edition](http://www.pearsonhighered.com/product?ISBN=0132805456) by Tony Gaddis.

The challenge itself consists of a number of pseudocode examples with an integrated tutorial that explains how to translate the pseudocode into Python.

If you want to test code that uses x_print in Python 3 outside of the CodeWars site, add this line to the top of the code:
```
x_print = print
```
